content.text: Explain what is meant by deceleration
Suggest one reason why the car does **not** begin to decelerate at \(t = 0\)
State the property of a distance–time graph that corresponds to speed
Using Fig. 1.1, determine the initial speed \(v\) of the car
v =
Fig. 1.1 is the distance–time graph for the car from \(t = 0\)
the deceleration of the car is greater than \(\frac{F}{m}\)
the deceleration is not constant
When the car is decelerating, there is a constant resistive force \(F\) on the car due to the brakes
The deceleration of the car is greater than \(\frac{F}{m}\) and is not constant
Explain why:
A car of mass \(m\) is travelling along a straight, horizontal road at a constant speed \(v\)
At time \(t = 0\), the driver of the car sees an obstruction in the road ahead of the car and applies the brakes
The car does **not** begin to decelerate at \(t = 0\)
State the form of the energy stored in the water in the reservoir that is used to generate electricity
Calculate the total pressure in the water at the turbine
pressure =   .........
The turbine has a cross-sectional area of \(3.5 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the force exerted on the turbine by the water
The turbine is \(150 \text{m}\) below the level of the water in the reservoir
Atmospheric pressure is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^{3}\)
The water flows to the turbine through a pipe of constant cross-sectional area
Explain why the kinetic energy of the water in the pipe remains constant as it flows through the pipe
Fig. 2.1 shows water stored in a reservoir behind a hydroelectric dam
Explain, in terms of molecules, how evaporation cools the water in the cloth
As the water in the cloth cools, so does the lemonade
Explain how electrons transfer thermal energy through the metal of the can
During a picnic on a warm, dry day, a metal can of lemonade is wrapped in a damp cloth
Evaporation cools the water in the cloth
On Fig. 4.1, sketch and label a diagram of a thermocouple that is used to determine the temperature of the sulfur as it cools to room temperature
Fig. 4.1
Describe briefly how the temperature of the sulfur in the beaker is deduced
Fig. 4.1 shows a beaker that contains molten sulfur at an initial temperature greater than \(400^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State one advantage of using a thermocouple to measure temperature rather than using a liquid-in-glass thermometer
A thermocouple is a device that is used as a thermometer
State what is meant by boiling point
Calculate the thermal energy produced by the heater in 60 s
thermal energy =   .........
The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \degree \text{C})\). The cold water that enters the tap is at \(22 \degree \text{C}\)
Calculate the rate at which water at its boiling point emerges from the tap
The immersion heater is powered by the mains at a voltage of 230 V. When the tap is opened, the heater switches on and the current in the heater is 13A
The metal tap is earthed and there is a fuse in the cable that connects the heater to the mains
1. Explain how the earth wire protects the user
Fig. 5.1 shows a kitchen tap that supplies instant boiling water
Cold water passes over an electric immersion heater inside the tap
The boiling point of water is \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
On a sunny day, the Sun warms the road
Describe how energy from the Sun reaches the Earth and warms the road
The temperature of the road is greater than the temperature of the sea
The surface of the road is black
Suggest **one** reason why the temperature of the road is greater than that of the sea
Describe how this affects the molecules of the air
A cyclist travelling along the road notices that a cool breeze is blowing from the sea to the land
Explain how convection produces this breeze. You may include a diagram if it helps your answer
The air above the road is heated by the warm road
Fig. 6.1 shows a road next to the sea
Rays of light, parallel to XY, are travelling towards the lens
Describe what happens to the light after it passes through the lens
On Fig. 7.1, mark and label with an F each of the two principal focuses of the lens
By drawing on Fig. 7.1, find the position of the image I of N and add image I to the diagram
State and explain whether I is a real or a virtual image
State the name given to a lens when it is used in this way
The small nail N, of height 1.2 cm, is positioned 2.0 cm to the left of the lens
Fig. 7.1 is a full-scale diagram of a small nail N in front of a thin converging lens. The line L represents the lens
The focal length of the lens is 3.0 cm
The mass of the magnet is 0.012 kg
Calculate the kinetic energy of the magnet when it reaches the lower end of the plastic tube
kinetic energy =
Explain why there is a current in the copper
The current in the copper produces a magnetic field of its own in the tube
The magnet falls much more slowly in the copper tube than in the plastic tube
Explain why the magnet falls more slowly in the copper tube
The magnet is then held at the top of the copper tube and released. As it falls through the copper tube, an electric current is generated in the copper
Fig. 8.1 shows two vertical, cylindrical tubes and a cylindrical magnet all held in a vacuum
(not to scale)
One tube is made of plastic and the other tube is made of copper. The two cylindrical tubes have identical dimensions
The magnetic field of the small, cylindrical magnet is extremely strong
Initially, the magnet is at rest at the top of the plastic tube
The magnet is released and it falls through the plastic tube without experiencing a resistive force. The magnet takes 0.67 s to fall to the lower end of the plastic tube
Describe the difference between a digital signal and an analogue signal. You may include a diagram if it helps your answer
Fig. 9.1 is the truth table for a logic gate X
State the name of logic gate X and draw the symbol that represents it
name
symbol
Logic gate Y is identical to logic gate X
Draw a combination of logic gates X and Y that behaves like an OR gate. Label the inputs A and B and label the output Q
Combinations of logic gates are used when digital signals are processed
State one similarity in the composition of their nuclei
Describe how a nucleus of hydrogen-3 differs from a nucleus of hydrogen-2
Explain why an extremely high temperature is needed when forcing these two nuclei together
Using nuclide notation, complete the equation for this reaction
In a nuclear fusion reactor, a nucleus of hydrogen-2 fuses with a nucleus of hydrogen-3 at an extremely high temperature. This fusion reaction produces an isotope of element X and releases a neutron
Two of the isotopes of hydrogen are hydrogen-2 ( \(_1^2 \text{H}\) ) and hydrogen-3 ( \(_1^3 \text{H}\) )
